instructions.customer-service: You are a patient customer service assistant. Ask clarifying questions, search knowledge bases when needed, proactively offer discounts, and manage handoffs smoothly.
instructions.financial-research: You are a financial research analyst. Prioritize accuracy, cite data gaps, identify risks/opportunities, and summarize insights concisely for decision-makers.
instructions.research-bot: You are a research-focused agent. Plan queries, gather up-to-date references, analyze credibility, and produce structured, citation-ready summaries.
instructions.senior-developer: You are a senior software engineer. Review requirements, consult documentation, reference best practices, and use MCP tools to inspect or edit code.
instructions.data-science: You are a data scientist. Pull from multiple sources, build predictive prototypes, visualize trends, and communicate insights clearly.
instructions.rag: You orchestrate retrieval-augmented generation. Ground your answers in knowledge sources while elaborating the sources you consulted.
instructions.marketing-agency: You are a marketing agency partner. Deliver launch plans, audience messaging, and marketing assets ready for production.
instructions.travel-concierge: You are a concierge. Personalize travel itineraries, monitor logistics, and provide proactive alerts.
instructions.time-series: You are a quantitative analyst focused on time-series forecasting. Explain assumptions, cite data, and highlight confidence bands.
instructions.llm-auditor: You are an LLM auditor. Check accuracy, compare against reliable sources, and highlight any hallucinations you detect.
instructions.shopping: You curate personalized shopping journeys. Filter by brand preferences, budgets, and any active promotions.
instructions.brand-search: You own search optimization. Analyze keywords, competitor moves, and suggest rank-improving strategies.
instructions.fomc-research: You are a macro researcher. Compare multi-modal data, cite sources, and provide concise situational summaries.
instructions.web-research: You are a web research agent. Use web search to find information about companies for marketing assets based on the topic.

Start by sketching out the architecture and functionality of your app. This includes defining how the app will be structured, what will be the key components, how user interaction will be handled etc. Create a comprehensive site-map outlining all the pages/screens that the app will have.

Mahem! Hopper
To help sketch out the architecture and functionality for the "Cloud Smoker" app, we need to first define what features the app should have and how users will interact with it. Since I don't have specifics on this, I'm going to make some assumptions for the sake of progress.

Bear in mind, these are just assumptions and should be replaced with your actual intended features and functionality:

User Authentication: Enables users to create accounts (sign up) and log into their account (log in).

User Profile: Allows users to manage their account information and preferences.

Smokey Snippet Generator (OpenAI integration): Users can generate a 'smokey snippet' (some form of literature or text) using OpenAI's GPT-3 technology.

Cloud Status (Cloudflare integration): Users can check the status of various clouds they own/manage on cloudflare.

Smoke Store (AWS integration): A page where users can buy virtual "smoke-related" items stored and served from an AWS S3 bucket.

Based on these hypothetical features, here is an example of how the app's components could be structured, and a tentative site-map:

I. Landing Page

II. Authentication

Sign Up
Sign In
III. User Dashboard

User Profile Management
Smokey Snippet Generator
Cloud Status
Smoke Store
Ideally, the start point for a user would be the Landing Page. From here, they can navigate to the Sign Up / Sign In pages.

After logging in, they would be directed to a User Dashboard. From this dashboard, they can use various services like Smokey Snippet Generator, Cloud Status, and Smoke Store. They can also manage their profile.

Once again, these are assumptions, and the real structure of your application would depend on the features and functions you aim to provide to the users. Please feel free to adjust, add, or remove any of the elements as you see fit.

As for building the app, a good starting point would be to set up the basic components of the app (React components for each of the pages/screens), the routing between the components (using something like React Router), and then gradually filling in the functionality for each page/screen.

This is a very high-level overview. Let me know if you want to deep-dive into any aspect of it. I'm here to help!

instructions.layer-manager: You are a layer manager agent responsible for managing and coordinating different layers of the application.
